clinical_study.brief_title: The Use of Self-reported Symptoms as a Proxy for Acute Organophosphate Poisoning Among Nepali Farmers
clinical_study.official_title: The Use of Self-reported Symptoms as a Proxy for Acute Organophosphate Poisoning Among Nepali Farmers: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Crossover Study

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate self-reported symptoms as a proxy for acute organophosphate poisoning by examining self-reported acute organophosphate poisoning symptoms and PchE activity in response to occupational acute organophosphate exposure among farmers in Nepal.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in self-reported acute organophosphate poisoning symptoms from baseline to follow up
primary_outcome.time_frame: Obtained just before (baseline) and 30 minutes after (baseline) each spray session
primary_outcome.description: Obtained using a structured questionnaire interview. The definition of symptoms was based on WHO's standardized list of clinical presentations of acute organophosphate poisoning.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Plasma Cholinesterase (PchE) activity from baseline to follow up
primary_outcome.time_frame: Obtained just before (baseline) and 30 minutes after (baseline) each spray session
primary_outcome.description: PchE activity was measured with a blood test using a Test-mate Che Cholinesterase System (Model 400) with a PchE Plasma Cholinesterase Assay Kit (Model 470).

arm_group.description: Initial spray session: organophosphate. Crossover spray session: placebo
Initial spray session: placebo. Crossover spray session: organophosphate

intervention.description: Chlorpyrifos 50% plus cypermethrin 5%, WHO Class II: Moderately hazardous
Multineem, WHO Class U: Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- male
- minimum age 18 years
- hand pressured backpack sprayer usage
- used to spray with moderately to extremely hazardous pesticides according to the World Health Organization's (WHO) Pesticide Hazard Classification
Exclusion Criteria:
- usual personal protective equipment use (respirator/mask with particulate filter, face shield, googles, gloves, boots, plastic poncho)
- unwilling to stay pesticide-free seven days prior to each of the two spray sessions
- medical conditions interfering with PchE activity (liver disease, acute infection, chronic malnutrition, heart attack, cancer, obstructive jaundice, inflammation caused by various diseases, or use of pyridostigmine drugs)
